data.question: Which hurricane is the only Pacific tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California?
data.context: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona, and [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages, along with heavy winds. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

text: The 1858 San Diego hurricane is the only Pacific tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California.

data.question: Which Pacific hurricane is known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California?
data.context: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona, and [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages, in [[California]], along with heavy winds. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona, and [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages in [[California]], along with heavy winds. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

data.context: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in [[Arizona]], [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona, and [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages in California, along with heavy winds. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

data.question: Which hurricane is the only Pacific tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California?
data.context: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in [[Arizona]], [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona, and [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages in California, along with heavy winds. It also affected places such as [[Idaho]] as a post-tropical remnant. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

text: The 1858 San Diego hurricane is the only Pacific tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California.

data.question: Which Pacific hurricane is known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California?
data.context: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in [[Arizona]], [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona. Many tropical cyclones have affected these areas in the 21st century, with a notable one being [[Hurricane Hilary]] in 2023, which caused large amounts of flooding and power outages in California, along with heavy winds. It also affected places such as [[Idaho]] as a post-tropical remnant. <ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

text: The 1858 San Diego hurricane is the only Pacific tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in California.

data.question: How many Pacific hurricanes have struck Hawaii?
data.context:
Additionally, three [[Pacific hurricane]]s struck [[Hawaii]], and one Pacific tropical cyclone brought hurricane-force winds to [[California]]. The tables list hurricanes by category on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]], based on winds that occurred in each state.
The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] is the only [[Pacific hurricane|Pacific]] tropical cyclone known to have produced hurricane-force winds in [[California]]; it affected [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] on October 2, 1858, though its center remained just offshore. In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Michael Chenoweth  |author2=Chris Landsea |name-list-style=amp|year=2004|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|publisher=American Meteorological Society|access-date=2008-01-26|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf}}</ref>

text: Three Pacific hurricanes have struck Hawaii.

In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona. data.question: Did Hurricane Dora (2023) make landfall in Hawaii?
data.context:
[[2023 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Dora|Hurricane Dora (2023)]] affected [[2023 Hawaii wildfires|wildfires in Hawaii]], "although there is some debate about how much influence the storm had as it passed about 500 miles south of the Hawaiian islands."{{cite web |author1=Dan Stillman |title=Unrelenting Hurricane Dora makes history by becoming a typhoon |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2023/08/11/hurricane-dora-typhoon-hawaii-record/ |publisher=The Washington Post |access-date=18 October 2023 |date=11 August 2023}} However, it is not included in this list since this is a list of storms producing hurricane force winds within the states and territories listed, not a list of hurricanes passing within 500 miles of Hawaii that made "history without making landfall."{{cite web |author1=Jennifer Robbins |title=Hurricane Dora makes history without making landfall |url=https://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/2023/08/12/hurricane-dora-makes-history-without-making-landfall/ |publisher=Hawaii News Now |access-date=18 October 2023 |date=12 August 2023}}

''Note: This section only includes tropical cyclones that occurred [[Territory of Hawaii|during or after 1900]], when [[Hawaii]] was acquired by the United States''
''This section does not include tropical cyclones that affected the [[Northwestern Hawaiian Islands]]''

text: No, Hurricane Dora (2023) did not make landfall in Hawaii. It passed about 500 miles south of the Hawaiian islands.

In the 20th century, only four tropical cyclones produced tropical storm force winds in the southwestern United States: a [[1939 California tropical storm|tropical storm]] in September 1939 in California, [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in October 1972 in Arizona, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in September 1976 in Arizona and California, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in September 1997 in Arizona. [[2023 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Dora|Hurricane Dora (2023)]] affected [[2023 Hawaii wildfires|wildfires in Hawaii]], "although there is some debate about how much influence the storm had as it passed about 500 miles south of the Hawaiian islands."<ref>{{cite web |author1=Dan Stillman |title=Unrelenting Hurricane Dora makes history by becoming a typhoon |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2023/08/11/hurricane-dora-typhoon-hawaii-record/ |publisher=The Washington Post |access-date=18 October 2023 |date=11 August 2023}}</ref> However, it is not included in this list since this is a list of storms producing hurricane-force winds within the states and territories listed, not a list of hurricanes passing within 500 miles of Hawaii that made "history without making landfall."<ref>{{cite web |author1=Jennifer Robbins |title=Hurricane Dora makes history without making landfall |url=https://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/2023/08/12/hurricane-dora-makes-history-without-making-landfall/ |publisher=Hawaii News Now |access-date=18 October 2023 |date=12 August 2023}}</ref>

data.question: How many North Atlantic hurricanes have produced hurricane-force winds in the United States since 1851?
data.context: The '''list of United States hurricanes''' includes all [[tropical cyclone]]s officially recorded to have produced sustained winds of greater than {{convert|74|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in the United States, which is the minimum threshold for [[tropical cyclone scales|hurricane]] intensity. The list, which is sorted by [[U.S. state]], begins in 1851 with the start of the official [[HURDAT|Atlantic hurricane database]] (HURDAT), as provided by the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]]'s Hurricane Research Division. Since 1851, a total of 307 [[North Atlantic hurricane]]s<!-- as of August 2023--> produced hurricane-force winds in 19 states along the [[East Coast of the United States|Atlantic coast]]. Some of these storms may not have made a direct landfall (i.e. remained just offshore) while producing hurricane-force winds on land; some of them may have weakened to a tropical storm or became extratropical before landfall but produced hurricane conditions on land while still a hurricane and some of them made landfall in an adjacent state but produced hurricane conditions over multiple states. This list does not include storms that only produced tropical storm conditions on land in the United States.

text: Since 1851, a total of 307 North Atlantic hurricanes have produced hurricane-force winds in the United States.

data.question: When does the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begin?
data.context:
{{Short description|Upcoming hurricane season in the Atlantic Ocean}} {{Draft topics|earth-and-environment}} {{AfC topic|other}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2021}} {{Infobox hurricane season|Basin=Atl|Year=2024|First storm formed=Season not started|Last storm dissipated=Season not started|Strongest storm name=|Strongest storm pressure=|Strongest storm winds=|Total depressions=|Damagespre=~|Damages=None|Fatalities=None|five seasons=[[2022 Atlantic hurricane season|2022]], [[2023 Atlantic hurricane season|2023]], '''2024''', ''[[Tropical cyclone naming#North Atlantic Ocean|2025]]'', ''[[Tropical cyclone naming#North Atlantic Ocean|2026]]''|Season timeline=|West Pacific season=2024 Pacific typhoon season|East Pacific season=2024 Pacific hurricane season|North Indian season=2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} The '''2024 Atlantic hurricane season''' is the future event for the annual [[Atlantic hurricane season]] in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. The season officially begins on June 1, 2024, and ends on November 30, 2024. These dates, adopted by convention, historically describe the period in each year when most subtropical or [[tropical cyclogenesis]] occurs in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] (over 97%). The [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC) will begin issuing regular Tropical Weather Outlooks on May 15, 2024, about two weeks prior to the start of the season. == Seasonal forecasts == {| class="toccolours" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; text-align:right; clear: right;" |+'''Predictions of tropical activity in the 2023 season''' | align="center" |'''Source''' | align="center" |'''Date''' | align="center" |'''Named
storms''' | align="center" |'''Hurricanes''' | align="center" |'''Major
hurricanes''' | align="center" |'''Ref''' |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Average (1991–2020)'' |14.4 |7.2 |3.2 | |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Record high activity'' |[[2020 Atlantic hurricane season|30]] |[[2005 Atlantic hurricane season|15]] |[[2020 Atlantic hurricane season|7]]† |{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Record low activity'' |[[1914 Atlantic hurricane season|1]] |[[1914 Atlantic hurricane season|0]]† |[[2013 Atlantic hurricane season|0]]† | |- | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;" |––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– |- | align="left" | | align="left" | | | | | |- | align="left" | | align="left" | | | | | |- | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;" |––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– |- | align="left" | | align="left" |'''Actual activity'''
|0 |0 |0 |- | colspan="5" |* May–November only
† Most recent of several such occurrences. ([[List of Atlantic hurricane records#Seasonal activity|See all]]) |} In advance of, and during, each hurricane season, several [[Tropical cyclone seasonal forecasting|forecasts of hurricane activity]] are issued by national meteorological services, scientific agencies, and noted hurricane experts. These include forecasters from the United States [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA)'s [[Climate Prediction Center]], Tropical Storm Risk (TSR), the United Kingdom's [[Met Office]] (UKMO), and Philip J. Klotzbach, [[William M. Gray]] and their associates at [[Colorado State University]] (CSU). The forecasts include weekly and monthly changes in significant factors that help determine the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a particular year. According to NOAA and CSU, the average [[Atlantic hurricane season]] between 1991 and 2020 contained roughly 14 tropical storms, seven hurricanes, three major hurricanes, and an [[accumulated cyclone energy]] (ACE) index of 72–111 units. Broadly speaking, ACE is a measure of the power of a tropical or subtropical storm multiplied by the length of time it existed. It is only calculated for full advisories on specific tropical and subtropical systems reaching or exceeding wind speeds of {{Cvt|39|mph}}.{{cite web|date=May 22, 2019|title=Background Information: North Atlantic Hurricane Season|url=https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/outlooks/Background.html|access-date=April 5, 2021|publisher=[[Climate Prediction Center]]|location=College Park, Maryland}} NOAA typically categorizes a season as above-average, average, or below-average based on the cumulative ACE index, but the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a hurricane season is sometimes also considered. === Pre-season forecasts === TBA == Storm names == {{Tropical cyclone naming}} The following [[Tropical cyclone naming|list of names]] will be used for named storms that form in the North Atlantic in 2024. Retired names, if any, will be announced by the World Meteorological Organization in the spring of 2025. The names not retired from this list will be used again in the 2030 season. This is the same list used in the [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season|2018 season]], with the exceptions of ''Francine'' and ''Milton'', which replaced ''[[Hurricane Florence|Florence]]'' and ''[[Hurricane Michael|Michael]]'', respectively. {| style="width:90%;" | * {{tcname unused|Alberto}} * {{tcname unused|Beryl}} * {{tcname unused|Chris}} * {{tcname unused|Debby}} * {{tcname unused|Ernesto}} * {{tcname unused|Francine}} * {{tcname unused|Gordon}} | * {{tcname unused|Helene}} * {{tcname unused|Isaac}} * {{tcname unused|Joyce}} * {{tcname unused|Kirk}} * {{tcname unused|Leslie}} * {{tcname unused|Milton}} * {{tcname unused|Nadine}} | * {{tcname unused|Oscar}} * {{tcname unused|Patty}} * {{tcname unused|Rafael}} * {{tcname unused|Sara}} * {{tcname unused|Tony}} * {{tcname unused|Valerie}} * {{tcname unused|William}} |} == Season effects == This is a table of all of the storms that have formed in the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. It includes their duration, names, intensities, areas affected, damages, and death totals. Deaths in parentheses are additional and indirect (an example of an indirect death would be a traffic accident), but were still related to that storm. Damage and deaths include totals while the storm was extratropical, a wave, or a low, and all of the damage figures are in 2023 USD. {{Saffir-Simpson small|align=center}} {{TC stats table start3|year=2023|basin=North Atlantic tropical cyclone|align=center}} {{TC stats table end3|num-cyclones=0|dates='''Season not started'''|max-winds=0 (0)|min-press=0|tot-areas=|tot-damage=0|tot-deaths=0}} == See also == * [[Weather of 2024]] * [[Tropical cyclones in 2024]] * [[Atlantic hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific typhoon season]] * [[2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]] * South-West Indian Ocean cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * Australian region cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 Australian region cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * South Pacific cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South Pacific cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] == References == {{reflist}} [[:Category:Atlantic hurricane seasons]] [[:Category:Tropical cyclones in 2023]]

text: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begins on June 1, 2024.

These include forecasters from the United States [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA)'s [[Climate Prediction Center]], Tropical Storm Risk (TSR), the United Kingdom's [[Met Office]] (UKMO), and Philip J. Klotzbach, [[William M. Gray]] and their associates at [[Colorado State University]] (CSU). The forecasts include weekly and monthly changes in significant factors that help determine the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a particular year. According to NOAA and CSU, the average [[Atlantic hurricane season]] between 1991 and 2020 contained roughly 14 tropical storms, seven hurricanes, three major hurricanes, and an [[accumulated cyclone energy]] (ACE) index of 72–111 units. Broadly speaking, ACE is a measure of the power of a tropical or subtropical storm multiplied by the length of time it existed. It is only calculated for full advisories on specific tropical and subtropical systems reaching or exceeding wind speeds of {{Cvt|39|mph}}.{{cite web|date=May 22, 2019|title=Background Information: North Atlantic Hurricane Season|url=https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/outlooks/Background.html|access-date=April 5, 2021|publisher=[[Climate Prediction Center]]|location=College Park, Maryland}} NOAA typically categorizes a season as above-average, average, or below-average based on the cumulative ACE index, but the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a hurricane season is sometimes also considered. === Pre-season forecasts === TBA == Storm names == {{Tropical cyclone naming}} The following [[Tropical cyclone naming|list of names]] will be used for named storms that form in the North Atlantic in 2024. Retired names, if any, will be announced by the World Meteorological Organization in the spring of 2025. The names not retired from this list will be used again in the 2030 season. This is the same list used in the [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season|2018 season]], with the exceptions of ''Francine'' and ''Milton'', which replaced ''[[Hurricane Florence|Florence]]'' and ''[[Hurricane Michael|Michael]]'', respectively. {| style="width:90%;" | * {{tcname unused|Alberto}} * {{tcname unused|Beryl}} * {{tcname unused|Chris}} * {{tcname unused|Debby}} * {{tcname unused|Ernesto}} * {{tcname unused|Francine}} * {{tcname unused|Gordon}} | * {{tcname unused|Helene}} * {{tcname unused|Isaac}} * {{tcname unused|Joyce}} * {{tcname unused|Kirk}} * {{tcname unused|Leslie}} * {{tcname unused|Milton}} * {{tcname unused|Nadine}} | * {{tcname unused|Oscar}} * {{tcname unused|Patty}} * {{tcname unused|Rafael}} * {{tcname unused|Sara}} * {{tcname unused|Tony}} * {{tcname unused|Valerie}} * {{tcname unused|William}} |} == Season effects == This is a table of all of the storms that have formed in the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. It includes their duration, names, intensities, areas affected, damages, and death totals. Deaths in parentheses are additional and indirect (an example of an indirect death would be a traffic accident), but were still related to that storm. Damage and deaths include totals while the storm was extratropical, a wave, or a low, and all of the damage figures are in 2023 USD. {{Saffir-Simpson small|align=center}} {{TC stats table start3|year=2023|basin=North Atlantic tropical cyclone|align=center}} {{TC stats table end3|num-cyclones=0|dates='''Season not started'''|max-winds=0 (0)|min-press=0|tot-areas=|tot-damage=0|tot-deaths=0}} == See also == * [[Weather of 2024]] * [[Tropical cyclones in 2024]] * [[Atlantic hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific typhoon season]] * [[2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]] * South-West Indian Ocean cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * Australian region cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 Australian region cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * South Pacific cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South Pacific cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] == References == {{reflist}} [[:Category:Atlantic hurricane seasons]] [[:Category:Tropical cyclones in 2023]]

text: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begins on June 1, 2024, and ends on November 30, 2024.

data.question: When does the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begin?
data.context:
{{Draft topics|earth-and-environment}} {{AfC topic|other}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2021}} {{Infobox hurricane season|Basin=Atl|Year=2024|First storm formed=Season not started|Last storm dissipated=Season not started|Strongest storm name=|Strongest storm pressure=|Strongest storm winds=|Total depressions=|Damagespre=~|Damages=None|Fatalities=None|five seasons=[[2022 Atlantic hurricane season|2022]], [[2023 Atlantic hurricane season|2023]], '''2024''', ''[[Tropical cyclone naming#North Atlantic Ocean|2025]]'', ''[[Tropical cyclone naming#North Atlantic Ocean|2026]]''|Season timeline=|West Pacific season=2024 Pacific typhoon season|East Pacific season=2024 Pacific hurricane season|North Indian season=2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season}} The '''2024 Atlantic hurricane season''' is the future event for the annual [[Atlantic hurricane season]] in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. The season officially begins on June 1, 2024, and ends on November 30, 2024. These dates, adopted by convention, historically describe the period in each year when most subtropical or [[tropical cyclogenesis]] occurs in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] (over 97%). The [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC) will begin issuing regular Tropical Weather Outlooks on May 15, 2024, about two weeks prior to the start of the season. == Seasonal forecasts == {| class="toccolours" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" style="float:right; margin-left:1em; text-align:right; clear: right;" |+'''Predictions of tropical activity in the 2023 season''' | align="center" |'''Source''' | align="center" |'''Date''' | align="center" |'''Named
storms''' | align="center" |'''Hurricanes''' | align="center" |'''Major
hurricanes''' | align="center" |'''Ref''' |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Average (1991–2020)'' |14.4 |7.2 |3.2 | |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Record high activity'' |[[2020 Atlantic hurricane season|30]] |[[2005 Atlantic hurricane season|15]] |[[2020 Atlantic hurricane season|7]]† |{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} |- | colspan="2" align="center" |''Record low activity'' |[[1914 Atlantic hurricane season|1]] |[[1914 Atlantic hurricane season|0]]† |[[2013 Atlantic hurricane season|0]]† | |- | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;" |––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– |- | align="left" | | align="left" | | | | | |- | align="left" | | align="left" | | | | | |- | colspan="6" style="text-align:center;" |––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– |- | align="left" | | align="left" |'''Actual activity'''
|0 |0 |0 |- | colspan="5" |* May–November only
† Most recent of several such occurrences. ([[List of Atlantic hurricane records#Seasonal activity|See all]]) |} In advance of, and during, each hurricane season, several [[Tropical cyclone seasonal forecasting|forecasts of hurricane activity]] are issued by national meteorological services, scientific agencies, and noted hurricane experts. These include forecasters from the United States [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA)'s [[Climate Prediction Center]], Tropical Storm Risk (TSR), the United Kingdom's [[Met Office]] (UKMO), and Philip J. Klotzbach, [[William M. Gray]] and their associates at [[Colorado State University]] (CSU). The forecasts include weekly and monthly changes in significant factors that help determine the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a particular year. According to NOAA and CSU, the average [[Atlantic hurricane season]] between 1991 and 2020 contained roughly 14 tropical storms, seven hurricanes, three major hurricanes, and an [[accumulated cyclone energy]] (ACE) index of 72–111 units. Broadly speaking, ACE is a measure of the power of a tropical or subtropical storm multiplied by the length of time it existed. It is only calculated for full advisories on specific tropical and subtropical systems reaching or exceeding wind speeds of {{Cvt|39|mph}}.{{cite web|date=May 22, 2019|title=Background Information: North Atlantic Hurricane Season|url=https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/outlooks/Background.html|access-date=April 5, 2021|publisher=[[Climate Prediction Center]]|location=College Park, Maryland}} NOAA typically categorizes a season as above-average, average, or below-average based on the cumulative ACE index, but the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a hurricane season is sometimes also considered. === Pre-season forecasts === TBA == Storm names == {{Tropical cyclone naming}} The following [[Tropical cyclone naming|list of names]] will be used for named storms that form in the North Atlantic in 2024. Retired names, if any, will be announced by the World Meteorological Organization in the spring of 2025. The names not retired from this list will be used again in the 2030 season. This is the same list used in the [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season|2018 season]], with the exceptions of ''Francine'' and ''Milton'', which replaced ''[[Hurricane Florence|Florence]]'' and ''[[Hurricane Michael|Michael]]'', respectively. {| style="width:90%;" | * {{tcname unused|Alberto}} * {{tcname unused|Beryl}} * {{tcname unused|Chris}} * {{tcname unused|Debby}} * {{tcname unused|Ernesto}} * {{tcname unused|Francine}} * {{tcname unused|Gordon}} | * {{tcname unused|Helene}} * {{tcname unused|Isaac}} * {{tcname unused|Joyce}} * {{tcname unused|Kirk}} * {{tcname unused|Leslie}} * {{tcname unused|Milton}} * {{tcname unused|Nadine}} | * {{tcname unused|Oscar}} * {{tcname unused|Patty}} * {{tcname unused|Rafael}} * {{tcname unused|Sara}} * {{tcname unused|Tony}} * {{tcname unused|Valerie}} * {{tcname unused|William}} |} == Season effects == This is a table of all of the storms that have formed in the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season. It includes their duration, names, intensities, areas affected, damages, and death totals. Deaths in parentheses are additional and indirect (an example of an indirect death would be a traffic accident), but were still related to that storm. Damage and deaths include totals while the storm was extratropical, a wave, or a low, and all of the damage figures are in 2024 USD. {{Saffir-Simpson small|align=center}} {{TC stats table start3|year=2023|basin=North Atlantic tropical cyclone|align=center}} {{TC stats table end3|num-cyclones=0|dates='''Season not started'''|max-winds=0 (0)|min-press=0|tot-areas=|tot-damage=0|tot-deaths=0}} == See also == * [[Weather of 2024]] * [[Tropical cyclones in 2024]] * [[Atlantic hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific typhoon season]] * [[2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]] * South-West Indian Ocean cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * Australian region cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 Australian region cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * South Pacific cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South Pacific cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] == References == {{reflist}} [[:Category:Atlantic hurricane seasons]] [[:Category:Tropical cyclones in 2024]]

According to NOAA and CSU, the average [[Atlantic hurricane season]] between 1991 and 2020 contained roughly 14 tropical storms, seven hurricanes, three major hurricanes, and an [[accumulated cyclone energy]] (ACE) index of 72–111 units. Broadly speaking, ACE is a measure of the power of a tropical or subtropical storm multiplied by the length of time it existed. It is only calculated for full advisories on specific tropical and subtropical systems reaching or exceeding wind speeds of {{Cvt|39|mph}}.{{cite web|date=May 22, 2019|title=Background Information: North Atlantic Hurricane Season|url=https://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/outlooks/Background.html|access-date=April 5, 2021|publisher=[[Climate Prediction Center]]|location=College Park, Maryland}} NOAA typically categorizes a season as above-average, average, or below-average based on the cumulative ACE index, but the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a hurricane season is sometimes also considered. === Pre-season forecasts === On December 11, 2023, TSR released their extened range outlook for the 2024 Atlantic season, predicting a very active year with 20 named storms, 9 hurricanes, and 4 major hurricanes, with an ACE Index of 160 units. == Storm names == {{Tropical cyclone naming}} The following [[Tropical cyclone naming|list of names]] will be used for named storms that form in the North Atlantic in 2024. Retired names, if any, will be announced by the World Meteorological Organization in the spring of 2025. The names not retired from this list will be used again in the 2030 season. This is the same list used in the [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season|2018 season]], with the exceptions of ''Francine'' and ''Milton'', which replaced ''[[Hurricane Florence|Florence]]'' and ''[[Hurricane Michael|Michael]]'', respectively. {| style="width:90%;" | * {{tcname unused|Alberto}} * {{tcname unused|Beryl}} * {{tcname unused|Chris}} * {{tcname unused|Debby}} * {{tcname unused|Ernesto}} * {{tcname unused|Francine}} * {{tcname unused|Gordon}} | * {{tcname unused|Helene}} * {{tcname unused|Isaac}} * {{tcname unused|Joyce}} * {{tcname unused|Kirk}} * {{tcname unused|Leslie}} * {{tcname unused|Milton}} * {{tcname unused|Nadine}} | * {{tcname unused|Oscar}} * {{tcname unused|Patty}} * {{tcname unused|Rafael}} * {{tcname unused|Sara}} * {{tcname unused|Tony}} * {{tcname unused|Valerie}} * {{tcname unused|William}} |} == Season effects == This is a table of all of the storms that have formed in the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. It includes their duration, names, intensities, areas affected, damages, and death totals. Deaths in parentheses are additional and indirect (an example of an indirect death would be a traffic accident), but were still related to that storm. Damage and deaths include totals while the storm was extratropical, a wave, or a low, and all of the damage figures are in 2023 USD. {{Saffir-Simpson small|align=center}} {{TC stats table start3|year=2023|basin=North Atlantic tropical cyclone|align=center}} {{TC stats table end3|num-cyclones=0|dates='''Season not started'''|max-winds=0 (0)|min-press=0|tot-areas=|tot-damage=0|tot-deaths=0}} == See also == * [[Weather of 2024]] * [[Tropical cyclones in 2024]] * [[Atlantic hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific hurricane season]] * [[2024 Pacific typhoon season]] * [[2024 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]] * South-West Indian Ocean cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * Australian region cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 Australian region cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] * South Pacific cyclone seasons: [[2023–24 South Pacific cyclone season|2023–24]], [[Tropical cyclone naming|2024–25]] == References == {{reflist}} [[:Category:Atlantic hurricane seasons]] [[:Category:Tropical cyclones in 2023]] CycloneIns EXTENDED CONFIRMED USERS 593 EDITS Privacy policy Terms of UseDesktop

data.question: When does the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begin and end?
data.context: #REDIRECT [[Atlantic hurricane season]]

text: The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begins on June 1, 2024, and ends on November 30, 2024.

data.question: When does the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season officially begin and end?
data.context:
The 2024 Atlantic hurricane season is the future event for the annual Atlantic hurricane season in the Northern Hemisphere. The season officially begins on June 1, 2024, and ends on November 30, 2024. These dates, adopted by convention, historically describe the period in each year when most subtropical or tropical cyclogenesis occurs in the Atlantic Ocean (over 97%). The National Hurricane Center (NHC) will begin issuing regular Tropical Weather Outlooks on May 15, 2024, about two weeks prior to the start of the season.
Seasonal forecasts
Predictions of tropical activity in the 2024 season

Actual activity

* May–November only
† Most recent of several such occurrences. (See all)
In advance of, and during, each hurricane season, several forecasts of hurricane activity are issued by national meteorological services, scientific agencies, and noted hurricane experts. These include forecasters from the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)'s Climate Prediction Center, Tropical Storm Risk (TSR), the United Kingdom's Met Office (UKMO), and Philip J. Klotzbach, William M. Gray and their associates at Colorado State University (CSU). The forecasts include weekly and monthly changes in significant factors that help determine the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a particular year. According to NOAA and CSU, the average Atlantic hurricane season between 1991 and 2020 contained roughly 14 tropical storms, seven hurricanes, three major hurricanes, and an accumulated cyclone energy (ACE) index of 72–111 units. Broadly speaking, ACE is a measure of the power of a tropical or subtropical storm multiplied by the length of time it existed. It is only calculated for full advisories on specific tropical and subtropical systems reaching or exceeding wind speeds of 39 mph (63 km/h).[3] NOAA typically categorizes a season as above-average, average, or below-average based on the cumulative ACE index, but the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes within a hurricane season is sometimes also considered.[3]
Pre-season forecasts
On December 11, 2023, TSR released their extened range outlook for the 2024 Atlantic season, predicting a very active year with 20 named storms, 9 hurricanes, and 4 major hurricanes, with an ACE Index of 160 units.[2]
Storm names
Main articles: Tropical cyclone naming, History of tropical cyclone naming, and List of historic tropical cyclone names
The following list of names will be used for named storms that form in the North Atlantic in 2024. Retired names, if any, will be announced by the World Meteorological Organization in the spring of 2025. The names not retired from this list will be used again in the 2030 season. This is the same list used in the 2018 season, with the exceptions of Francine and Milton, which replaced Florence and Michael, respectively.

Season effects
This is a table of all of the storms that have formed in the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. It includes their duration, names, intensities, areas affected, damages, and death totals. Deaths in parentheses are additional and indirect (an example of an indirect death would be a traffic accident), but were still related to that storm. Damage and deaths include totals while the storm was extratropical, a wave, or a low, and all of the damage figures are in 2023 USD.
